The deluded concepts that the sūtras teach are all called non-natured.
They're all said to be devoid of nature.
They only have names.
If we part with names, then there's no deluded conception to be had.
Then there would be no deluded perceptions to be had.
Since deluded perception is absent, it's not explained as existing.
It's also said not to exist.
It's not possible to further define the noble teaching.
It's called clinging to medicine to cause illness.
The Tathāgata shows people that.
There's really no remaining meaning.'
The above five teachings show the two supernormal powers of doctrine and explanation.
It's the use of knowledge of the meaning of good words and consciousness.
They discriminate the foolish and the non-faithful.
It's to help advance self and others.
This is the end of the liberation of the true teaching.

惝 (Chang兩切 惝惑失意貌).

He looks (Qi luoche 睇也).
